document.docTitle: Terpenoids from the Chinese liverwort Odontoschisma grosseverrucosum and their antifungal virulence activity

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Terpenoids from the Chinese liverwort Odontoschisma grosseverrucosum and their antifungal virulence activity

mods:name.mods:affiliation: ∗ & Department of Natural Product Chemistry, Key Lab of Chemical Biology of Ministry of Education, School of Pharmaceutical Sciences, Shandong University, Jinan,

paragraph.docTitle:
Terpenoids from the Chinese liverwort
Odontoschisma grosseverrucosum
and their antifungal virulence activity

document.paragraph: Jiao-Zhen Zhang a , Yan Zong a , Xue Wang a , Xue-Yang Jin a , Ming Zhang a , Wen-Qiang Chang a ,

Wang Chen d , Hong-Xiang Lou
a, ∗

paragraph.emphasis:
Department of Natural Product Chemistry, Key Lab of Chemical Biology of Ministry of Education, School of Pharmaceutical Sciences, Shandong University, Jinan,
250012, China
School of Pharmacy, Linyi University, Linyi, 276000, China
School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shandong University, Jinan, 250010, China
Vitamin D Research Institute, Shanxi University of Technology, Hanzhong, 723000, China

document.paragraph: A R T I C L E I N F O

subSection.paragraph:
Odontoschisma grosseverrucosum Stephani
(cephaloziaceae)
Liverworts
Terpenoids
Odongrossin A−H
Anti-virulence
A B S T R A C T

Eight undescribed terpenoids, namely, odongrossins A−H, together with two known terpenoids were isolated from
Odontoschisma grosseverrucosum Stephani (Cephaloziaceae)
. Their structures were established based on NMR data, electronic circular dichroism (ECD) calculations, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction measurements. Odongrossin A and odongrossin G displayed moderate anti-virulence activities against CDR1 -and CDR2 -efflux-pump-deficient
Candida albicans DSY
654. Further investigation of odongrossin A revealed that it inhibited adhesion and biofilm formation on
C. albicans DSY
654. The results regarding the transcription levels of genes demonstrated that odongrossin A could regulate the expression of genes that are associated with the virulence of
C. albicans DSY
654.

Candida albicans
is one of the normal flora of the healthy human body ( Sudbery et al., 2004 ).
C. albicans
can be a pathogen if the normal host defence mechanisms are impaired ( Netea et al., 2008 ), and virulence factors are the cause of fungal infection by
C. albicans ( Borges et al., 2017 )
. Antifungal resistance that is due to the upregulation of efflux pumps is prevalent in clinical
Candida
isolates ( Coste et al., 2007 ; White, 1997 ). Many terpenoids that have been isolated from liverworts exhibit potent antifungal properties ( Zheng et al., 2018 ). Our previous study identified various liverwort-derived terpenoids (which include eudesmane sesquiterpenoid and labdane lactone), namely, potential efflux pump substrates (PEPSs), that are active against strains that are deficient in efflux pumps but inactive against wild-type strains ( Li et al., 2017 , 2019 ). Some PEPSs produced antifungal activity against wild-type and azole-resistant
C. albicans
after glucosylation ( Chang et al., 2017 ), triphenylphosphonium cation conjugation ( Chang et al., 2018 ) and co-application with efflux pump inhibitors ( Li et al., 2017 ). However, they are typically undetected in routine antifungal screening. Thus, the identification of previously undescribed terpenoids from genus
Odontoschisma
with PEPS properties substantially expands drug discovery channels for antifungal agents.

Herein, we report in detail the isolation and structural elucidation of eight previously undescribed terpenoids (which include two rare dilospirane-type diterpenoids) ( 1–8 ), together with two known congeners ( 9–10 ) ( Fig. 1 ) that were isolated from the liverwort
Odontoschisma grosseverrucosum Stephani (Cephaloziaceae)
, which was collected from Wuyanling National Nature Reserve, Lishui City, Zhejiang Province , People's Republic of China , and the evaluation of their antifungal virulence activity.

caption.paragraph: 1 H NMR spectroscopic data for compounds 1−3.

subSection.paragraph:
Odongrossin A ( 1 ) was obtained as a yellowish oil. The molecular formula of 1 , namely, C 20 H 34 O 2 ( m/z 329.2452 [M + Na] + , calcd 329.2451), which has four degrees of unsaturation, was established based on its HRESIMS data. The IR spectrum showed absorptions at 3504 and 1713 cm −1 , which were due to one hydroxyl group and one carbonyl group, respectively. The 1 H NMR data ( Table 1 ) showed signals of five methyl groups [ δ H 0.82 (d, J = 6.8 Hz, H 3 -19), 0.92 (d, J = 6.8 Hz, H 3 -18), 1.05 (s, H 3 -20), 1.08 (s, H 3 -16) and 2.13 (s, H 3 -15)] and two highly shielded methines, which were attributed to a tetrasubstituted cyclopropane ring [ δ H 0.22 (ddd, J = 10.1, 6.9, 5.5 Hz, H-9), and 0.32 (dt, J = 7.1, 5.1 Hz, H-11)]. The 13 C NMR ( Table 3 ) and the HSQC spectra revealed 20 carbon signals, which were attributed to five methyls, seven methylenes, four methines (including one oxygenated methine; δ
C
60.1), and four quaternary carbons (including an oxygenated quaternary carbon and a ketone carbonyl; δ
C
85.6 and 209.5, respectively). Due to the presence of one carbonyl group, the four degrees of unsaturation demonstrated that 1 was a tricyclic structure. The NMR spectroscopic data of 1 closely resembled that of dilospirane B ( Ioannou et al., 2011 ), except for the presence of signals for an oxygenated quaternary carbon at δ
C
85.6 and a methyl group [0.92 (d, J = 6.8 Hz, H 3 -18); δ
C
17.5] in 1 . The presence of a tetrasubstituted ternary ring was supported by HMBC correlations from H 3 - 20 to C-8, C-9 and C-11, and from H-11 to C-7, C-8, C-9, C-10 and C-20, along with the linkage moiety CH (9)− CH (11) from the 1 H– 1 H COSY correlations of H-9 ( δ H 0.22)/H-11 ( δ H 0.32). These data provided evidence of one hydroxyl group at C-4, and the double bond between C-17 and C-18 was hydrogenated in 1 . This was also supported by the HMBC correlations from H 3 -19 to C-4, C-17 and C-18. Odongrossin A has been regarded as an unnamed skeleton, which we wish to name the dilospirane skeleton since dilospirane B features previously described carbocyclic units ( Ioannou et al., 2011 ). This was the first dilospiranetype diterpenoid that was isolated from liverworts. The NOESY correlations (Fig. S6) of H 3 -16/H-9 and H-9/H 3 -20 indicated that they were co-facial, and they were assigned as α -oriented. The NOESY correlations of H 3 -20/H-7 α , H-7 β /H-5 and H-7 β /H-11 indicated that H-5 and H-11 were β -oriented. The NOESY correlation of OH-4/H 3 -16 recorded in DMSO‑ d 6 (Fig. S7) indicated that OH-4 was α -oriented. Accordingly, the relative configuration of 1 was supported. The experimental ECD spectrum perfectly accorded with the trends of the calculated curves for 1 (Fig. S83 A ). Thus, the absolute configuration of 1 was assigned as 1 S , 4 S , 5 S , 8 R , 9 S , 11 S .

paragraph.tableNote: Chemical shifts ( δ ) are expressed in ppm, and J values are presented in Hz. a Recorded at 600 MHz in CDCl.

subSection.paragraph:
The chemical formula of odongrossin B ( 2 ), which is a yellowish oil, namely, C 18 H 32 O 2 ( m/z 281.2477 [M + H] + , (calcd 281.2475) was established based on HRESIMS data, which suggested that it had one fewer degree of unsaturation than 1 . The IR spectrum showed absorptions at 3351 cm −1 , which were due to hydroxyl groups. The NMR spectroscopic data of 2 ( Tables 1 and 3 ) exhibited similar characteristic signals to those of 1 , except for the presence of a signal for oxygenated methylene at δ
C
63.7 and the disappearance of a ketone carbonyl and a methyl. These data provided evidence that the acetyl group at C- 13 in 1 was replaced by one hydroxyl group in 2 . Herein, a degraded dilospirane-type diterpenoid skeleton was suggested. The relative configuration of 2 was assigned to be the same as that of 1 based on similar NOESY correlations (Fig. S17) of H-9/H 3 -20 ( δ H 1.07), H-9/H 3 -16 ( δ H 1.10), H 3 -20/H-7 α , H-7 β /H-5, and H-7 β /H-11. The NOESY correlation of OH-4/H
3 -16 in
DMSO‑ d 6 indicated that OH-4 was α -oriented (Fig. S18). The ECD data (Fig. S83 A ) of 2 were consistent with those of 1, which supported the absolute structure of 1 S , 4 S , 5 S , 8 S , 9 S , 11 S . Odongrossin B was demonstrated to be an enantiomerically pure compound via liquid chromatography (HPLC) analyses on a Waters Delta 600 system with a chiral column and a Waters 996 photodiode array detector (Fig. S85).

Odongrossin C ( 3 ) was isolated as colourless needles. The molecular formula of 3 , namely, C 16 H 20 O 3 , as determined by HRESIMS ( m/z 283.1305 [M + Na] + , calcd 283.1305) and 13 C NMR data, corresponds to seven degrees of unsaturation. The IR absorption band at 1764 cm −1 suggested the presence of a carbonyl functional group. An analysis of the 1D NMR data ( Tables 1 and 3 ) of 3 and the HSQC spectrum revealed 16 carbon signals that were attributable to four methyls (one methoxyl at δ
C
55.5), one methylene, four sp 3 methines (one oxygenated at δ
C
76.5), two sp 2 methines ( δ
C
107.9 and 130.8), and five quaternary methines (four olefinic carbons at δ
C
125.5, 126.4, 138.6 and 157.1, and one carbonyl at δ
C
179.1). Herein, a cadinane-type (bicycle [4.4.0] decane) sesquiterpenoid skeleton ( Queiroga et al., 1996 ) was suggested. A benzene ring was determined from the HMBC correlations from H 3 -15 ( δ H 2.20) to C-2, C-3 and C-4, from H-4 to C-2 and C-6, and from H-1 to C-2, C-3 and C-5. The 1 H– 1 H COSY correlations of H-7/H 2 -8, H 2 -8/ H-9 and H-9/H-10, along with the key HMBC correlations from H 3 -14 ( δ H 1.42) to C-6, C-7 and C-8, led to the identification of a hexatomic ring. The NMR spectroscopic data of 3 were similar to that of 2- methoxy-calamenene-14-carboxylic acid ( Morimoto et al., 2009 ), except for the appearance of an oxygenated methine, as judged by the carbon resonance at δ
C
76.5. These data provided evidence of a lactone ring between C-9 and C- 12 in 3 . This was also supported by the HMBC correlations from H 3 -13 ( δ H 1.51) to C-10, C-11 and C-12, and from H-9 to C-11 and C-12. Thus, the planar structure of 3 was elucidated. NOESY correlations of H-9/H-7 and H 3 -13/H-10, together with single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis with Mo K α radiation ( Fig. 2C ), were used to assign the relative configuration of 3 . The absolute configuration of 3 was determined by comparing the experimental and calculated ECD spectra (Fig. S83B). Thus, the stereochemistry of 3 was identified as 7 S , 9 R , 10 S , 11 R .

Odongrossin D ( 4 ) was obtained as a colourless oil. The HRESIMS spectrum showed the [M + Na] + ion peak at m/z 327.2294 (calcd 327.2295) was ascribed to the molecular formula C 20 H 32 O 2 , which corresponds to five degrees of unsaturation. The IR spectrum showed absorptions at 3463 and 1708 cm −1 , which were due to one hydroxyl group and one carbonyl group, respectively. The 1 H NMR spectrum ( Table 2 ) displayed the signals of four methyls at δ H 1.29 (s, H 3 -16), 0.90 (d, J = 6.7 Hz, H 3 -17), 1.01 (s, H 3 -19), and 0.71 (s, H 3 -20), along with a monosubstituted vinyl (– CH ] CH 2 ) at δ H 5.89 (dd, J = 17.4, 10.8 Hz, H-14), 5.09 (dd, J = 10.8, 0.9 Hz, H-15a) and 5.23 (dd, J = 17.4, 0.9 Hz, H-15 b). Additionally, one disubstituted vinyl at δ H 4.56 (br s, H-18a) and 4.43 (br s, H-18 b) was observed. The 13 C NMR ( Table 3 ) and HSQC spectra supported the presence of two terminal double bond ( δ
C
158.2, 103.2; 144.9, 112.4), a carbonyl ketone at C-7 ( δ
C
214.2), and an oxygenated quaternary carbon ( δ
C
73.3). A clerodane-type diterpenoid skeleton ( Silva et al., 2011 ) was suggested. The data of 4 corresponded to a similar structure to that of chelodane ( Rudi and Kashman, 1992 ), except for the appearance of a carbonyl ketone, as judged by the carbon resonance at δ
C
214.2. The HMBC correlations from H 2 -6 to C-7 and from H-8 to C-7 indicated that the carbonyl was located at C-7. The NOESY correlations (Fig. S38) of H 3 -17/H 3 -20 and H 3 -20/H 3 -19 indicated that they were co-facial and α -oriented. The NOESY correlation of H-10/H-8 indicated the β -orientation of the two protons. Accordingly, the relative configuration of 4 was determined. The absolute configuration was further supported by ECD calculations, as presented in Fig. S83 C . Thus, 4 was identified as 5 R , 8 S , 9 R , 10 R .

Odongrossin E ( 5 ) was isolated as a colourless oil, and it was assigned the molecular formula C 20 H 34 O 2 based on its HRESIMS data ( m/ z 306.2550 [M] + , calcd 306.2553) and 13 C NMR spectrum, which corresponds to four degrees of unsaturation. The NMR spectroscopic data of 5 ( Tables 2 and 3 ) exhibited similar characteristic signals to those of 4 , except that the ketone carbonyl group at C- 7 in 4 was replaced by a hydroxyl group in 5 , which was further supported by the HMBC correlations (Fig. S46) from H 3 -17 ( δ H 0.98) to C-7 ( δ
C
73.7) and by the observation of spin system CH 2 (6)− CH (7)− CH (8) in the 1 H– 1 H COSY spectrum. The NOESY correlations of H-10/H-8, H-8/H-6 β , H-6 α / H 3 -19 ( δ H 1.34), H 3 -19/H 3 -20 ( δ H 1.00) and H 3 -17/H-7 demonstrated that the relative configuration of 5 was consistent with that of 4 . Moreover, the CD curve (Fig. S52) of 5 showed the same trend as that of 4 . Accordingly, the stereochemistry of 5 was established as 5 R , 7 S , 8 S , 9 R , 10 R .

Odongrossin F ( 6 ) was obtained as a colourless oil, and it was assigned the same molecular formula as 5 based on its HRESIMS data ( m/ z 306.2550 [M] + , calcd 306.2553), which corresponds to four degrees of unsaturation. The NMR spectroscopic data ( Tables 2 and 3 ) of 6 closely resembled that of 5 , except that the location of the hydroxyl group at C- 7 in 5 shifted to C-6 ( δ
C
74.2) in 6 , which was further supported by the HMBC correlations (Fig. S56) from H 3 -19 ( δ H 1.06) to C-6 and by the spin system CH (6)− CH 2 (7)− CH (8) that was observed in the 1 H– 1 H COSY spectrum. Accordingly, the planar structure of 6 was established. The relative configuration of 6 was determined by the NOESY correlations of H 3 -19/H 3 -20 ( δ H 0.72), H 3 -20/H 3 -17 ( δ H 0.81), H-8/H-10 and H-10/H-6, which was consistent with that of 4 . According to the CD data (Fig. S62), the absolute configuration of 6 was identified as 5 R , 6 S , 8 R , 9 S , 10 R .

Odongrossin G ( 7 ) was isolated as a colourless oil. Its molecular formula was determined to be C 20 H 30 O 2 based on its HRESIMS data ( m/ z 320.2581 [M + NH 4 ] + , calcd 320.2584), which correspond to six degrees of unsaturation. The IR spectrum showed an absorption peak at 1711 cm −1 , which was due to the carbonyl group. The 1 H and 13 C NMR data ( Tables 2 and 3 ) revealed four methyls (including two secondary methyls and one vinyl methyl), six methylenes, a three-substituted trans-olefine, a two-substituted trans-olefine [ δ H 5.01 (m) and 5.00 (m); δ
C
126.4 and 139.6], a disubstituted vinyl [ δ H 5.05 (br s) and 4.83 (br s); δ
C
116.1 and 141.3], and two carbonyl groups ( δ
C
215.1 and 204.8). The gross structure of 7 was constructed via a detailed analysis of its 2D NMR data (Figs. S66 and S67). These data of 7 revealed a similar structure to that of denudatenone B ( Hashimoto et al., 1998b ), except that the location of the double bond was transferred from Δ 7 to Δ 8(17) in 7 , which was further supported by the 1 H– 1 H COSY correlations of H 2 - 17/H 2 -7 and H 2 -17/H 2 -9 and by the HMBC correlations from H 2 -17 to C-6, C-7, C-8 and C-9. A vibsane-type diterpenoid skeleton ( Shen et al., 2002 ) was suggested. The NOESY correlations of H 3 -15 ( δ H 1.00)/H-2 α , H-2 β /H-13 β , H 3 -15/H-3, H-3/H-7 α , H-3/H-5 α and H-9 β /H-17a indicated the relative configuration of 7 . In addition, the NOESY correlations of H-3/H-5 α and H-11/H-9 β suggested the presence of two E - double bonds at C-3 and C-10, respectively. Accordingly, the relative configuration of 7 was determined. The absolute configuration was supported by ECD calculations, as presented in Fig. S83D. Thus, 7 was identified as 1 S , 3 E , 10 E .

caption.paragraph: Fig. 2. Selected HMBC (H→C), 1 H– 1 H COSY (H▬H) and NOESY correlations (H↔H) of 1 (A/B), 4 (D/E), 8 (F\G) and the X-ray crystallographic structure of 3 (C).
1 H NMR spectroscopic data for compounds 4−8.

tableNote.paragraph: Chemical shifts ( δ ) are expressed in ppm, and J values are presented in Hz.
a Recorded at 600 MHz in CDCl.
3 b Recorded at 400 MHz in CDCl.

caption.paragraph: 13 C NMR spectroscopic data for compounds 1−8.

tableNote.paragraph: a Data were measured in CDCl at 150 MHz.
3 b Data were measured in CDCl at 100 MHz.

subSection.paragraph:
Odongrossin H ( 8 ) was obtained as colourless platelets with a molecular formula of C 20 H 30 O 3 , as determined based on the HRESIMS data at m/z 336.2536 [M + NH 4 ] + (calcd 336.2533), which suggested six degrees of unsaturation. The IR spectrum showed absorptions at 3406 and 1770 cm −1 , which were due to one hydroxyl group and one carbonyl group, respectively. The 1 H NMR data ( Table 2 ) demonstrated the presence of two tertiary methyls [ δ H 1.01 (s, H 3 -17) and δ H 0.83 (s, H 3 - 20)]; eight methylenes, including one oxygenated methylene [ δ H 4.45 (d, J = 8.2 Hz, H α -19) and 3.91 (d, J = 8.2 Hz, H β -19)]; four methines, including one oxygenated methine [ δ H 4.34 (m, H-2)]; and a monosubstituted double bond [ δ H 5.82 (dd, J = 17.5, 10.7 Hz, H-15), 4.87 (d, J = 10.7 Hz, Ha-16) and 4.94 (d, J = 17.5 Hz, Hb-16)], which correspond to a dolabrane-type diterpenoid ( Kitahara et al., 1964 ). The 13 C NMR data ( Table 3 ) showed one ester carbonyl at δ
C
176.9 (C-18). The 1D NMR spectroscopic data of 8 closely resembled those of the previously described notolutesin A ( 9 ) ( Wang et al., 2014 ), except that an E -double bond at C-3 was reduced in 8 . This was also supported by the HMBC correlation from H 2 -1 and H 2 -3 to C-2 and by the 1 H– 1 H COSY correlation between H-2 and H 2 -3. The NOESY correlation (Fig. S78) of H-2/H 3 -20 suggested that H-2 and H 3 -20 were co-facial and α - oriented. In addition, the NOESY correlations of H 3 -20/H-12 α , H-12 β / H 3 -17, H-12 β /H-10, H-10/H-19 β , H-19 β /H-4 and H-19 β /H-8 implied that they were β -oriented. Accordingly, the relative configuration of 8 was determined. The absolute configuration was confirmed by ECD calculations, as presented in Fig. S83E. Consequently, 8 was established as 2 S , 4 R , 5 R , 8 S , 9 S , 10 R , 13 S .

heading.emphasis: 2.2. Results on the anti-virulence activity of the compounds

subSection.paragraph:
Candida albicans
has developed numerous virulence factors for causing disease in a host, such as hyphal formation, adhesion, and biofilm formation. The targeting of virulence factors has been proposed as a potential therapy for candidiasis ( Huang, 2012 ). Thus, we evaluated the effects of compounds 1–10 on the morphological transitions of
C. albicans DSY
654 and wild-type strain SC 5314 ( Zhang et al., 2017 ). The results demonstrated that compounds 1 and 7 exhibited antifungal activity by inhibiting the hyphal formation of DSY 654 ( Table S1 ). Between them, 1 displayed the more potent inhibitory effect, which could restrict
C. albicans
in yeast form at the concentration of 16 μ g/mL within 6 h ( Fig. 3A ). Therefore, we investigate the inhibitory performance of 1 against adhesion and biofilm formation. The results demonstrated that 1 exhibited potent, dose-dependent inhibitory activity against the adhesion and biofilm formation of
C. albicans
( Fig. 3B, C, 3D, and 3E ). Above all, 1 has the potential to inhibit adhesion, hyphal formation and biofilm formation of
C. albicans
.

To identify the underlying mechanisms of the inhibited morphological transition, we investigated the transcription levels of genes that are related to the hyphal formation and cell adhesion in
C. albicans
using real-time RT-PCR. According to Fig. 3F , the expressions of adhesion-related genes ( HWP1 , ECE1 and ALS3 ) were downregulated by 1 at 6 h. Furthermore, the hyphae-formation-regulated genes in the Ras1-cAMP-PKA signalling pathway were downregulated to varying extents, as CDC35 was downregulated in the presence of 1 , which can result in a decrease of the intracellular cAMP content. In addition, the genes that are associated with the MAPKA pathway ( CST20 and HST7 ) and transcription factors ( TEC1, UME6, and BCR1 ) were downregulated to varying extents. These results suggest that 1 likely regulates the expression of genes that are related to the virulence of
C. albicans
to retard the yeast-to-hyphae transition.

In summary, eight previously undescribed terpenoids ( 1–8 ), which include a dilospirane skeleton in compounds 1–2 , a cadinane skeleton in compound 3 , a clerodane skeleton in compounds 4–6 , a vibsane skeleton in compound 7 and a dolabrane skeleton in compound 8 , together with two known terpenoids ( 9–10 ) were isolated from
O. grosseverrucosum
. A plausible biogenetic pathway of compounds 1–3 and 7 was proposed ( Fig. 4 ). The characteristic skeleton of compound 1 was derived from dolastane diterpenoid ( Kelecom and Teixeira, 1988 ) via selective oxidation, C 9 – C 14 cleavage and cyclopropanation, and compound 2 was transformed from 1 under Baeyer-Villiger type oxidation condition. The aromatic rings and lactone of compound 3 possessed cadinane sesquiterpenoid framework ( Nagashima et al., 1994 ) could be constructed by aromatization and C- 12 oxidation, respectively. Compound 7 was formed similarly through late-stage oxidation and functionalization of vibsane diterpenoid. Two compounds could inhibit the yeast-filamentous growth transition of
C. albicans DSY
654 to various degrees but were inactive against SC 5314. Additional studies of 1 suggested that it could significantly attenuate the virulence of
C. albicans
by inhibiting hyphal formation, adhesion, and biofilm formation and by regulating the expression of virulence-related genes. Thus, searching for PEPSs from liverworts may be an efficient strategy for discovering previously undescribed compounds for fighting clinically relevant fungal infections.

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 3. (A) The inhibition effect of compound 1 on the morphologic transition. (B) The inhibitory effect of compound 1 on the adhesion of
C. albicans
to A549 cells. (C) The number of adherent cells was determined by measuring the total size of the picture. The bars represent means ± SDs. * denotes P <0.05, **P <0.01, and ***P <0.001. (D) The inhibition effect of compound 1 on
C. albicans biofilm
formation. (E) The biofilm was detected with a CCK-8 reduction assay. The bars represent means ± SDs. * denotes P <0.05, and ** denotes P <0.01. (F) The downregulation of genes that are involved in virulence of
C. albicans .
The bars represent means ± SDs. * denotes P <0.05, **P <0.01, and ***P <0.001.

subSection.paragraph: Optical rotations were acquired by an Anton Paar MCP 200 polarimeter at 20 ° C . HRESIMS data ( 1 , 3 , 4 , 7 and 8 ) were obtained using a Thermo Electron LTQ-Orbitrap XL, and HRESIMS data ( 2 , 5 and 6 ) were obtained using an Agilent 6520 Series Accurate-Mass Q-TOF LC/ MS. ECD spectra were obtained using a Chirascan spectropolarimeter. UV data were recorded using a UV-2550 spectrophotometer (Shimadzu, Japan ). IR spectra were measured on a Nicolet iN 10 Micro FTIR spectrometer. NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker Avance DRX-600 spectrometer ( 1 H: 600 MHz, 13 C : 150 MHz) and a Bruker Avance AVIII-400 spectrometer (1H: 400 MHz, 13 C : 100 MHz) using TMS as an internal standard. HPLC was conducted on an Agilent 1200-series instrument with ZORBAX SB-C 18 5 μ m columns (4.6 × 250 mm and 9.4 × 250 mm ). HPLC analyses of 2 were conducted on a Waters Delta 600 system with a CHIRALPAK AD-H 5 μ m column (4.6 × 250 mm ) and a Waters 996 photodiode array detector. MCI gel (CHP20P, 75–150 mm , Mitsubishi Chemical Industries Ltd.), silica gel (200–300 mesh; Qingdao Haiyang Chemical Co. Ltd.), Sephadex LH-20 (25–100 μ m; Pharmacia), and reversed-phase C 18 silica gel (150–200 mesh, Merck) were used for column chromatography. Precoated silica gel GF-254 glass plates (Qingdao Haiyang Chemical Co. Ltd., Qingdao, China ) were used for TLC. The compounds were visualized under UV ( 254 nm ) light and by spraying with H 2 SO 4 –EtOH (1:9, v/v) and subsequently heating.

caption.paragraph: Fig. 4. Plausible biogenetic pathway for 1–3 and 7 .

subSection.paragraph:
Whole plants of
Odontoschisma grosseverrucosum Stephani (Cephaloziaceae)
were collected from Wuyanling National Nature Reserve (coordinates 119° 37′ 08’’ − 119° 50′ 00″ E , 27° 20′ 52’’ − 27° 48′ 39″ N , 1724 m a.s.l.), Lishui City, Zhejiang Province , People's Republic of China , in May 2018 (wet season), and they were identified by Dr. Jinchuan Zhou (College of Pharmacy, Linyi University). A voucher specimen (No. 20180518011) has been deposited at the Department of Natural Products Chemistry, School of Pharmaceutical Sciences, Shandong University, People's Republic of China .

The air-dried and milled plant materials of
O. grosseverrucosum
(560.0 g) were extracted with 95% EtOH (3 × 1.5 L , each for one week) at room temperature and filtered. The filtrate was evaporated under a reduced pressure at 40 ° C to yield the crude extract ( 28.5 g ), which was separated via MCI gel column (12 × 3.3 cm ) chromatography (MeOH–H 2 O, 3:7 to 9:1) and yielded fractions 1–7. Fraction 2 ( 3.3 g ) was chromatographed using a silica gel column (9 × 3.3 cm ) [petroleum ether (60–90 ° C )-acetone, 200:1 to 0:1] to yield subfractions 2 A− 2 N. Subfraction 2 B ( 268.2 mg ) was purified using HPLC (MeOH–H 2 O, 73:27, 1.5 mL/min) to yield 1 ( 137.8 mg ) and 3 ( 6.9 mg ). Subfraction 2D ( 297.2 mg ) was subjected to an RP-C 18 silica gel column (10 × 1.8 cm ) (MeOH–H 2 O, 5:5 to 10:0) to yield subfractions A−F. Subfraction B was purified using HPLC (MeOH–H 2 O, 75:25, 1.5 mL/ min) to yield 4 (11.0 mg). Subfraction C was purified using HPLC (MeOH–H 2 O, 85:15, 1.5 mL/min) to yield 10 (7.0 mg). Subfraction 2 E ( 167.3 mg ) was applied to a Sephadex LH-20 column (110 × 1.8 cm ) (MeOH) and a RP-18 silica gel column (10 × 1.8 cm ) (MeOH/H 2 O, 5:5 to 10:0) to yield subfractions A−H. Subfraction E was purified via HPLC (MeOH–H 2 O, 75:25, 1.5 mL/min) to yield 5 ( 10.4 mg ). Subfraction D was purified via HPLC (MeOH–H 2 O, 73:27, 1.5 mL/min) to yield 2 ( 4.1 mg ) and 6 ( 1.3 mg ). Fraction 2G ( 115.9 mg ) was purified using HPLC (MeOH–H 2 O, 75:25, 1.5 mL/min) to yield 9 (18.0 mg). Fraction 2H (135.0 mg) was applied to a Sephadex LH-20 column (110 × 1.8 cm ) (MeOH) and a RP-18 silica gel column (10 × 1.8 cm ) (MeOH–H 2 O, 5:5 to 10:0), which was followed by purification with HPLC (MeOH–H 2 O, 70:30, 1.5 mL/min), to yield 8 ( 3.5 mg ). Fraction 3 ( 1.5 g ) was chromatographed using a silica gel column (8 × 3.3 cm ) [petroleum ether (60–90 ° C )-acetone, 200:1 to 0:1] to yield subfractions 3 A-3K. Fraction 3 A ( 419.2 mg ) was applied to a Sephadex LH-20 column (90 × 2.2 cm ) (MeOH), which was followed by purification with HPLC (MeOH–H 2 O, 80:20, 1.5 mL/min), to yield 7 (6.0 mg). All compounds were detected under UV ( 254 nm ) light and by spraying with H 2 SO 4 –EtOH (1:9, v/v) and heating.

Yellowish oil; [ α ] D 25 +3.2 ( c 0.30 MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 200 (3.80) nm; ECD (MeOH) 217 (Δ ε −1.42) nm; IR ν max 3504, 2933, 1713, 1454, 1360, 1163, and 962 cm −1 ; 1 H and 13 C NMR data, see Tables 1 and 3 ; HRESIMS m/z 329.2452 [M + Na] + (calcd for C 20 H 34 O 2 Na, 329.2451).

Yellowish oil; [ α ] D 25 +0.22 ( c 0.20 MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 232 (2.93) nm; ECD (MeOH) 215 (Δ ε −0.25) nm; IR ν max 3351, 2940, 1451, 1382, 1143, 1049, and 964 cm −1 ; 1 H and 13 C NMR data, see Tables 1 and 3 ; HRESIMS m/z 281.2477 [M + H] + (calcd for C 18 H 33 O 2 , 281.2475).

Colourless crystals (MeOH); mp 73–74 ° C ; [ α ] D 25 −4.6 ( c 0.10 MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 203 (3.78) nm, 286 (2.58) nm; ECD (MeOH) 228 (Δ ε −0.65) nm, 242 (Δ ε 0.19) nm; IR ν max 3348, 2965, 2927, 1764, 1501, 1250, 1007, and 882 cm −1 ; 1 H and 13 C NMR data, see Tables 1 and 3 ; HRESIMS m/z 283.1305 [M + Na] + (calcd for C 16 H 20 O 3 Na, 283.1305).

Colourless oil; [ α ] D 25 +43 ( c 1.00 MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 200 (3.36) nm; ECD (MeOH) 289 (Δ ε 0.19) nm, 203 (Δ ε −2.06) nm; IR ν max 3463, 3083, 2971, 2939, 2875, 1708, 1639, 1445, 918, and 891 cm −1 ; 1 H and 13 C NMR data, see Tables 2 and 3 ; HRESIMS m/z 327.2294 [M + Na] + (calcd for C 20 H 32 O 2 Na, 327.2295).

Colourless oil; [ α ] D 25 +13 ( c 0.05 MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 200 (3.41) nm; ECD (MeOH) 200 (Δ ε −2.06) nm; IR ν max 3352, 2938, 2902, 1594, 1026, 870, and 706 cm −1 ; 1 H and 13 C NMR data, see Tables 2 and 3 ; HRESIMS m/z 306.2550 [M] + (calcd for C 20 H 34 O 2 , 306.2553).

Colourless oil; [ α ] D 25 +12 ( c 0.05 MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 200 (2.84) nm; ECD (MeOH) 201 (Δ ε −2.03) nm, 228 (Δ ε 0.07) nm; IR ν max 3301, 2931, 2873, 1671, 1453, 1378, 1021, 859, and 700 cm −1 ; 1 H and 13 C NMR data, see Tables 2 and 3 ; HRESIMS m/z 306.2550 [M] + (calcd for C 20 H 34 O 2 , 306.2553).

Colourless oil; [ α ] D 25 +71 ( c 0.30 MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 200 (3.81) nm; ECD (MeOH) 231 (Δ ε −0.83) nm, 301 (Δ ε 2.15) nm; IR ν max 2968, 2932, 1711, 1641, 1465, 1383, 982, and 898 cm −1 ; 1 H and 13 C NMR data, see Tables 2 and 3 ; HRESIMS m/z 320.2581 [M + NH 4 ] + (calcd for C 20 H 34 O 2 N, 320.2584).

Colourless oil; [ α ] D 25 −10 ( c 0.05 MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 200 (2.80) nm, 257 (2.22) nm; ECD (MeOH) 217 (Δ ε −0.13) nm, 253 (Δ ε 0.14) nm; IR ν max 3406, 3080, 2930, 1770, 1453, 1377, and 909 cm −1 ; 1 H and 13 C NMR data, see Tables 2 and 3 ; HRESIMS m/z 336.2536 [M + NH 4 ] + (calcd for C 20 H 34 O 3 N, 336.2533).

One suitable crystal of 3 was obtained via recrystallization from MeOH, and its structure was analysed using a Bruker D8 venture diffractometer. The crystal was maintained at 301 (2) K during data collection. The structure was solved with the ShelXS structure solution program using direct methods and refined with the ShelXL-2014/7 refinement package using least-squares minimization.

The following settings were used in all calculations: C 16 H 20 O 3 , M = 260.14 g /mol, monoclinic, space group P 21, a = 8.9681 (19) Å , b = 5.4929(10) Å , c = 14.623 (3) Å , β = 93.476 (8)°, V = 719.0 (2) Å 3 , Z = 2,
Dcalcd
= 1.202 g /cm 3 , μ (Mo K α ) = 0.711 mm −1 , F (000) = 280, and 3226 measured reflections (2.275° ≤ 2θ ≤ 26.017°), of which 2269 are unique. The final R 1 was 0.0562 (> 2sigma(I)), and wR 2 was 0.1421 (all data). The flack parameter was 1.6(10). The detailed crystallographic data for 3 have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre as supplementary publication number CCDC 1967375. The data can be obtained free of charge via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/products/csd/request.

Wild-type strain SC 5314 ( Zhang et al., 2017 ) and CDR1 -and CDR2 - efflux-pump-deficient strain DSY 654 ( Chang et al., 2018 ) were used in this study. The cells were cultured and incubated as previously described ( Zhang et al., 2017 ). Human lung epithelial cell line A 549 was used in this study and cultured as previously described ( Li et al., 2016 ).

heading.emphasis: 4.6. Effect of compounds on the phenotypic transition of C. albicans

subSection.paragraph:
We examined the effects of compound s on hyphal growth using a modified broth microdilution ( Chang et al., 2012 ).
C. albicans
strains DSY654 and SC5314 (1 × 10 5 cells/mL) were exposed to various concentrations of compounds (0–32 μ g/mL) in RPMI1640 and incubated at 37 °C without shaking. The morphology of
C. albicans
was observed by microscope (scale bars: 100 μ m) at 6 h.

heading.emphasis: 4.7. Effect of compound 1 on the fungal adherence to A 549 cells

subSection.paragraph:
A 549 cells (2 × 10 4 cells/well) were cultured at 37 ° C for 24 h in the RPMI 1640 medium with 10% foetal bovine serum (FBS) and penicillin/streptomycin. Then, the supernatants were decanted, and the unbound cells were removed by washing the plates with PBS three times. In each well, 500 μ L of the
C. albicans DSY
654 cell suspension (1 × 10 6 cells/mL) that was mixed with a suitable concentration of 1 (0, 2, 4, 8, 16, and 32 μ g/mL) was plated. After the incubation at 37 ° C for 90 min, the supernatants were decanted, and the unbound cells were removed by washing the plates with PBS three times. Then, the cells were fixed for 30 min by using 4% paraformaldehyde, and the adherent
C. albicans
cells were stained with Calcofluor White. After staining, the unbound Calcofluor White was washed with PBS , and the adherent
C. albicans
cells were observed using an Olympus fluorescence microscope (scale bars: 100 μ m) and counted ( Moyes et al., 2016 ).

heading.emphasis: 4.8. Effect of compound 1 on C. albicans biofilm formation

subSection.paragraph:
The effect of 1 on the biofilm formation of
C. albicans
strain DSY654 was tested via a CCK-8 reduction assay in 96-well microtiter plates ( Liu et al., 2016 ). A 100- μ L DSY654 cell suspension (1 × 10 6 cells/mL in RPMI1640 medium) was added to a 96-well flat-bottom plate with concentrations of 0, 2, 4, 8, 16, and 32 μ g/mL of compound 1 , and 2 μ g/ mL of FLC served as the positive control. After the plates were incubated at 37 °C for 24 h, the supernatants were discarded, and the nonadhered cells were removed by washing three times with PBS. To a 96- well plate, 100 μ L of PBS buffer and 10 μ L of the CCK-8 solution were added, and the samples were incubated for 4 h at 37 °C. The absorbance at a wavelength of 450 nm (OD450) was measured, and images of the effect of 1 on the biofilms were captured by an Olympus fluorescence microscope (Olympus IX71, Olympus, Tokyo , Japan ). (scale bars: 100 μ m).

Quantitative real-time PCR was used to investigate the expression of hyphal-related genes under the treatment of 1 ( Zhao et al., 2013 ).
C. albicans DSY
654 (5 × 10 6 cells/mL in the RPMI 1640 medium) was challenged with 1 at a suitable concentration of 32 μ g/mL at 37 ° C for 6 h with shaking at 200 rpm. At the end of the incubation period, cells were collected and washed twice with PBS . The total RNA was isolated via a hot phenol method ( Wu et al., 2008 ), and cDNA was synthesized using a cDNA synthesis kit (TaKaRa Biotechnology, Dalian, China ). PCR was conducted with the SYBR Green master mix (TaKaRa Biotechnology, Dalian, China ) in an Eppendorf Mastercycler Real-Time PCR System. The primer sequences used for gene amplification are listed in Table S2. A housekeeping gene, namely, 18 S rRNA, was used as an internal control.
The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.

This work was supported financially by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (Nos. 81874293, 81630093, and 81773786). The authors are grateful to Mr. S. Q. Wang for the NMR measurements, Mrs. J. Xing for the HRESIMS measurements, and Ms. J. Z. Zhang and Dr. Y. N. Qiao for the structural determination via single-crystal X-ray diffraction.
Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https:// doi.org/10.1016/j.phytochem.2020.112341.
